citations.narrative:
* The front tables had enclosures with animals for exhibit, two rabbits were being exhibited in an enclosure setup on the
concrete below and in front of these tables. There were enclosures that were constructed of solid material or aquarium
type of enclosures. These enclosures were on top of the table use to exhibit animals. The licensee or employees or
handlers could not see over the top of these enclosures to have a clear view of the rabbits housed on the ground in front
of the tables. Two younger girls and an adult women were observed reaching into the enclosure petting the rabbits. Also,
the fencing was accidently moved for the rabbits by one of the younger girls. This was not notice by the employees during
exhibit. Facing the front table, on the right end, was a kangaroo housed on the concrete in a temporary enclosure. The
employee was not present for a duration during exhibiting to observe the public around this animal. Later the employee
watching the Kangaroo had a primate on their shoulder. This employee was on the side of the tables with the kangaroo
and within proximity to the viewing public members. The primate had free access to the public and could have injured
someone or itself. These animals did not have sufficient distance, no barrier and could have injured the public or
themselves. There was not a sufficient number of employees to observed, from all angles, the exhibiting between the
public and the animals.
For safety assurance, and the prevention of injury to the four animals and public during exhibiting, all animals must have
sufficient distance and or barriers between the animals and viewing public. There must be at all times a sufficient number
of employees to observe all the animals and public.
This TRA inspection was conducted at the Thurston/Dakota Co., Fair grounds.
To be corrected by: 16-August-2023, or this date forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
* The front tables had enclosures with animals for exhibit, two rabbits were being exhibited in an enclosure setup on the 
concrete below and in front of these tables. There were enclosures that were constructed of solid material or aquarium 
type of enclosures. These enclosures were on top of the table use to exhibit animals. The licensee or employees or 
handlers could not see over the top of these enclosures to have a clear view of the rabbits housed on the ground in front 
of the tables. Two younger girls and an adult women were observed reaching into the enclosure petting the rabbits. Also, 
the fencing was accidently moved for the rabbits by one of the younger girls. This was not notice by the employees during 
exhibit. Facing the front table, on the right end, was a kangaroo housed on the concrete in a temporary enclosure. The 
employee was not present for a duration during exhibiting to observe the public around this animal. Later the employee 
watching the Kangaroo had a primate on their shoulder. This employee was on the side of the tables with the kangaroo 
and within proximity to the viewing public members. The primate had free access to the public and could have injured 
someone or itself. These animals did not have sufficient distance, no barrier and could have injured the public or 
themselves. There was not a sufficient number of employees to observed, from all angles, the exhibiting between the 
public and the animals.  
 
For safety assurance, and the prevention of injury to the four animals and public during exhibiting, all animals must have 
sufficient distance and or barriers between the animals and viewing public. There must be at all times a sufficient number 
of employees to observe all the animals and public.  
 
This TRA inspection was conducted at the Thurston/Dakota Co., Fair grounds.  
 
To be corrected by: 16-August-2023, or this date forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
